article:
Palladian Architecture

Palladian architecture is a style of building that was inspired by the designs of the 16th-century Italian architect Andrea Palladio. Characterized by grandeur, symmetry, and classical elements, Palladian architecture has had a profound influence on Western building design for centuries. This article explores the evolution of Palladian architecture, from its origins in 16th-century Italy to its spread throughout Europe and beyond.

# Palladio's Architecture

Andrea Palladio was a Venetian architect who is widely regarded as one of the most influential architects in history. Born in 1508, Palladio was trained as a stonemason and later worked as an architect in Vicenza, Italy. His designs were heavily influenced by classical Roman architecture, which he studied extensively during his travels to Rome. Palladio's buildings were characterized by their grand scale, symmetry, and use of classical elements such as columns, arches, and domes.

Palladio's most famous works include the Villa Capra, also known as the Villa Rotonda, and the Teatro Olimpico in Vicenza. The Villa Capra is considered one of the greatest buildings of all time, and its design has been imitated countless times around the world. The villa's symmetrical facade, with its central dome and flanking wings, has become an iconic representation of Palladian architecture.

# Venetian and Palladian Windows

One of the most distinctive features of Palladian architecture is the use of Venetian and Palladian windows. A Venetian window is a type of window that consists of three parts: a central section with a rounded arch, flanked by two smaller sections with square or rectangular tops. A Palladian window is similar, but with a central section that is taller and narrower than the flanking sections.

Venetian and Palladian windows were used extensively in Palladio's buildings, and they have since become a hallmark of Palladian architecture. These windows are often used to create a sense of grandeur and symmetry, and they can be found in buildings around the world.

# Early Palladianism

After Palladio's death in 1580, his designs continued to influence architecture in Italy and beyond. Many architects, including Vincenzo Scamozzi and Baldassare Longhena, were inspired by Palladio's work and created their own Palladian-style buildings.

In the 17th century, Palladianism began to spread throughout Europe. Architects such as Inigo Jones in England and Salomon de Caus in France were influenced by Palladio's designs, and they created their own Palladian-style buildings.

# Neo-Palladianism

In the 18th century, a new wave of Palladianism emerged, known as Neo-Palladianism. This movement was characterized by a renewed interest in classical architecture and a more rigid adherence to Palladio's designs.

Neo-Palladianism was popularized by architects such as William Kent and Lord Burlington, who built numerous Palladian-style buildings in England. The movement also spread to other parts of Europe, including Ireland and North America.

## English Palladian Architecture

English Palladian architecture was a major phenomenon in the 18th century. Architects such as William Kent and Lord Burlington built numerous Palladian-style buildings, including country houses, churches, and public buildings.

One of the most famous examples of English Palladian architecture is the Chiswick House, designed by Lord Burlington in the 1720s. This villa is considered one of the greatest buildings of the 18th century, and its design has been imitated countless times.

## Irish Palladian Architecture

Irish Palladian architecture was also popular in the 18th century. Architects such as Nathaniel Clements and James Hoban built numerous Palladian-style buildings, including country houses and public buildings.

One of the most famous examples of Irish Palladian architecture is the Castletown House, designed by Alessandro Galilei in the 1720s. This house is considered one of the greatest buildings of the 18th century, and its design has been imitated countless times.

## North American Palladian Architecture

Palladian architecture was also popular in North America, particularly in the 18th century. Architects such as Thomas Jefferson and James Hoban built numerous Palladian-style buildings, including country houses and public buildings.

One of the most famous examples of North American Palladian architecture is the Monticello, designed by Thomas Jefferson in the 1770s. This house is considered one of the greatest buildings of the 18th century, and its design has been imitated countless times.

## Palladianism Elsewhere

Palladianism also spread to other parts of the world, including Australia, South Africa, and South America. Architects such as Francis Greenway in Australia and Antoni Gaudí in South America were influenced by Palladio's designs, and they created their own Palladian-style buildings.

# Legacy

Palladian architecture has had a profound influence on Western building design for centuries. Its emphasis on grandeur, symmetry, and classical elements has inspired countless architects and builders around the world.

Palladian architecture has also had a significant impact on popular culture. Its use of classical elements and grand scale has influenced everything from film sets to theme parks.

article:
2022 Oslo Shooting

The 2022 Oslo shooting was a mass shooting that occurred on June 25, 2022, in Oslo, Norway. The attack took place in the city's nightlife district, specifically at a popular gay bar, leaving multiple people dead and injured.

# Shooting

On the evening of June 25, 2022, a gunman opened fire at the London Pub, a well-known gay bar in Oslo's nightlife district. The shooting occurred during the city's annual Pride celebrations. The attacker, later identified as a 42-year-old Norwegian man with an Iranian background, began firing at patrons outside the bar before entering the venue and continuing the attack. Witnesses described the scene as chaotic, with people running for cover and screaming.

The shooter was armed with a semi-automatic rifle and a handgun, which were later found at the scene. He was apprehended by police shortly after the attack, at around 1:15 a.m. local time. The suspect was taken into custody and questioned by authorities.

# Victims

The shooting resulted in the deaths of two people, both men in their 50s and 60s. A further 21 people were injured, including several who sustained serious injuries. The victims were rushed to nearby hospitals, where they received medical attention.

The two deceased victims were later identified as a 54-year-old man and a 60-year-old man, both of whom were regular patrons of the London Pub. The injured victims included several people who were shot, as well as others who suffered injuries while fleeing the scene.

# Investigation

The investigation into the shooting was led by the Oslo Police District, with assistance from the Norwegian National Authority for Investigation and Prosecution of Economic and Environmental Crime (Økokrim) and the Norwegian Intelligence Service (NIS).

Police searched the suspect's home and seized several items, including computers, phones, and documents. The investigation focused on the suspect's motives, with authorities exploring possible links to terrorism, as well as the suspect's background and mental health.

# Trial in 2024

The trial of the suspect is scheduled to take place in 2024. The suspect, who has been charged with terrorism and murder, is expected to face a lengthy prison sentence if convicted.

## Charges against a female detainee in Syria

In a separate development, a female detainee in Syria was charged in connection with the Oslo shooting. The woman, who is believed to have ties to the suspect, was accused of providing support to the attacker.

The charges against the woman were based on evidence gathered by Norwegian authorities, who worked in cooperation with their Syrian counterparts. The woman's exact role in the attack remains unclear, but authorities believe she may have played a significant part in the planning and preparation of the shooting.

# Aftermath

The Oslo shooting had a profound impact on the city and its residents. The attack sparked widespread shock and grief, with many people attending vigils and memorial services to pay their respects to the victims.

The shooting also raised concerns about the safety of Oslo's LGBTQ+ community, with many people expressing fears about the potential for further attacks. In response, authorities increased security measures in the city, including deploying additional police officers to patrol the streets.

# Reactions

## Domestic

The Oslo shooting was widely condemned by Norwegian politicians and community leaders. Prime Minister Jonas Gahr Støre described the attack as "terrible" and "unacceptable," while opposition leader Erna Solberg called for increased security measures to protect the LGBTQ+ community.

The shooting also sparked a national debate about gun control and mental health, with many people calling for stricter laws and improved support services.

## International

The Oslo shooting was condemned by leaders around the world, including EU officials, who expressed solidarity with the Norwegian people. The United States, the United Kingdom, and other countries also offered condolences and support to the victims and their families.

# Analysis

The Oslo shooting was a traumatic event that highlighted the ongoing threat of terrorism and violence in Europe. The attack also raised important questions about the safety and security of LGBTQ+ communities, who continue to face discrimination and persecution in many parts of the world.

The shooting also underscored the need for increased cooperation and information-sharing between law enforcement agencies, both domestically and internationally. By working together, authorities can better prevent and respond to attacks, and bring perpetrators to justice.

article:
2023 ATP Challenger Tour

The 2023 ATP Challenger Tour is the 46th season of the ATP Challenger Tour, which is the secondary professional tennis circuit organized by the Association of Tennis Professionals (ATP). The calendar comprises 184 tournaments, with prize money ranging from $40,000 to $220,000.

#Schedule

##January

The first month of the season saw 12 tournaments taking place across the globe. The month kicked off with the Bendigo International in Australia, where Ernesto Escobedo claimed the singles title. In the United States, the Orlando Open and the Columbus Challenger were held, with Brandon Holt and Jordan Thompson emerging as champions, respectively. In Europe, the Koblenz Open and the Oeiras Indoors were won by Peter Gojowczyk and Joris De Loore, respectively.

##February

February saw 13 tournaments take place, with the biggest event being the Bengaluru Open in India, which offered a prize money of $220,000. The tournament was won by Max Purcell, who defeated James Duckworth in the final. In the United States, the Dallas Open and the Cleveland Open were won by Yibing Wu and Aleksandar Kovacevic, respectively. In Europe, the Antalya Challenger and the Cherbourg Challenger were won by Fábián Marozsán and Holger Rune, respectively.

##March

March saw 17 tournaments take place, with the biggest event being the Phoenix Challenger in the United States, which offered a prize money of $175,000. The tournament was won by Nuno Borges, who defeated Alexander Shevchenko in the final. In Europe, the Biel/Bienne Challenger and the Sanremo Challenger were won by Jurij Rodionov and Holger Rune, respectively. In South America, the Santiago Challenger and the Concepción Challenger were won by Hugo Dellien and Federico Delbonis, respectively.

##April

April saw 15 tournaments take place, with the biggest event being the Sarasota Open in the United States, which offered a prize money of $175,000. The tournament was won by Daniel Altmaier, who defeated Aleksandar Kovacevic in the final. In Europe, the Barcelona Challenger and the Madrid Challenger were won by Matteo Gigante and Joris De Loore, respectively. In Asia, the Seoul Challenger and the Busan Challenger were won by Kwon Soon-woo and Aleksandar Kovacevic, respectively.

##May

May saw 17 tournaments take place, with the biggest event being the Aix-en-Provence Open in France, which offered a prize money of $175,000. The tournament was won by Benjamin Bonzi, who defeated Grégoire Barrère in the final. In the United States, the Savannah Challenger and the Tallahassee Challenger were won by Facundo Bagnis and Facundo Mena, respectively. In Europe, the Heilbronn Challenger and the Poznań Challenger were won by Matteo Arnaldi and Arthur Fils, respectively.

##June

June saw 15 tournaments take place, with the biggest event being the Nottingham Open in the United Kingdom, which offered a prize money of $175,000. The tournament was won by Andy Murray, who defeated Arthur Fils in the final. In Europe, the Bratislava Challenger and the Lyon Challenger were won by Vitaliy Sachko and Félix Auger-Aliassime, respectively. In Asia, the Hengyang Challenger and the Chengdu Challenger were won by Sun Fajing and Zhang Zhizhen, respectively.

##July

July saw 12 tournaments take place, with the biggest event being the Iași Challenger in Romania, which offered a prize money of $175,000. The tournament was won by Duje Ajduković, who defeated Jorge Martínez in the final. In Europe, the San Benedetto Challenger and the Amersfoort Challenger were won by Matteo Arnaldi and Emil Ruusuvuori, respectively. In North America, the Winnipeg Challenger and the Lexington Challenger were won by Enzo Couacaud and Steve Johnson, respectively.

##August

August saw 13 tournaments take place, with the biggest event being the Vancouver Open in Canada, which offered a prize money of $175,000. The tournament was won by Marcos Giron, who defeated Fernando Verdasco in the final. In Europe, the Meerbusch Challenger and the Cordenons Challenger were won by Tomás Barrios Vera and Matteo Gigante, respectively. In Asia, the Nanchang Challenger and the Chengdu Challenger were won by Dudi Sela and Zhang Zhizhen, respectively.

##September

September saw 12 tournaments take place, with the biggest event being the Istanbul Challenger in Turkey, which offered a prize money of $175,000. The tournament was won by Radu Albot, who defeated Lukáš Klein in the final. In Europe, the Sibiu Challenger and the Genoa Challenger were won by Nerman Fatić and Thiago Agustín Tirante, respectively. In Asia, the Kaohsiung Challenger and the Taipei Challenger were won by Tung-Lin Wu and Kwon Soon-woo, respectively.

##October

October saw 15 tournaments take place, with the biggest event being the Fairfield Challenger in the United States, which offered a prize money of $175,000. The tournament was won by Michael Mmoh, who defeated Alexander Ritschard in the final. In Europe, the Ortisei Challenger and the Brest Challenger were won by Marco Cecchinato and Grégoire Barrère, respectively. In Asia, the Seoul Challenger and the Busan Challenger were won by Kwon Soon-woo and Aleksandar Kovacevic, respectively.

##November

November saw 12 tournaments take place, with the biggest event being the Champaign-Urbana Challenger in the United States, which offered a prize money of $175,000. The tournament was won by Ben Shelton, who defeated Aleksandar Kovacevic in the final. In Europe, the Andria Challenger and the Maia Challenger were won by Leandro Riedi and Luca Van Assche, respectively. In Asia, the Kobe Challenger and the Yokkaichi Challenger were won by Yosuke Watanuki and Yuta Shimizu, respectively.

#Cancelled tournaments

Due to the COVID-19 pandemic, several tournaments were cancelled or postponed. These include the Zhuhai Challenger, the Guangzhou Challenger, and the Ningbo Challenger.

article:
Bath City F.C.

Bath City Football Club is a professional association football club based in Bath, Somerset, England. Founded in 1889, the club has a rich history and has played at various levels of English football. The team currently competes in the National League South, the sixth tier of the English football league system.

# History

## Formation and early years (1889–1925)

Bath City was formed in 1889 by the amalgamation of two local clubs, Bath AFC and Bath Rangers. The new club was initially known as Bath City and played friendly matches against local teams. In 1891, the club joined the Western League, but it was not until 1898 that they began to compete in the Somerset Senior League. Bath City won the Somerset Senior League in 1903 and were subsequently elected to the Western League.

## Large crowds and missing out on Football League (1925–1958)

In the 1920s, Bath City experienced a period of significant growth, with attendances at their matches increasing substantially. During the 1924-25 season, the club averaged crowds of over 4,000, which was a remarkable achievement for a non-League team at that time. However, despite their success on the pitch and the growth in popularity, Bath City were unable to gain election to the Football League. The club continued to compete in the Western League and later the Southern League, but they were unable to make the step up to the Football League.

## Glory, yoyo years and nationwide football (1958–1996)

The 1958-59 season marked a significant turning point for Bath City. The club won the Southern League Championship and were subsequently elected to the Football League. However, their stay in the Football League was short-lived, as they were relegated back to the Southern League after just one season. Over the next few decades, Bath City experienced a series of promotions and relegations, earning the nickname "yoyo club". Despite this, the club continued to compete at a national level, reaching the third round of the FA Cup on several occasions.

## Decline and subsequent relegation (1996–2017)

In the 1990s, Bath City began to experience a decline in fortunes. The club was relegated from the Football Conference to the Southern League in 1997 and continued to struggle, eventually dropping down to the Southern League Division One South. Despite efforts to regain their former glory, Bath City were unable to climb back up the divisions and remained in the lower levels of non-League football for many years.

## The Gill Era (2017–present)

In 2017, Bath City was taken over by a new ownership group, led by Jerry Gill. The new ownership brought significant investment and a renewed sense of optimism to the club. Under Gill's leadership, Bath City began to experience a resurgence, earning promotion back to the National League South in 2019. The club continues to compete at this level, with a renewed focus on developing young players and establishing a sustainable future.

# Badge

The Bath City badge features a stylized image of the Royal Crescent, a famous landmark in the city of Bath. The badge also includes the club's motto, "Sola Nobilitas Virtus", which is Latin for "Virtue Alone is Noble".

# Stadiums

## 1889: The North Parade Ground

Bath City's first home was the North Parade Ground, a public park in the city of Bath. The club played at this venue from 1889 to 1900.

## 1900–1919: Belvoir Castle

In 1900, Bath City moved to Belvoir Castle, a large estate on the outskirts of Bath. The club played at this venue until 1919.

## 1919–1932: Lambridge

In 1919, Bath City moved to Lambridge, a new stadium that was specifically built for the club. The stadium had a capacity of over 5,000 and was the club's home until 1932.

## 1932–present: Twerton Park

In 1932, Bath City moved to Twerton Park, a new stadium that was built on the site of a former recreation ground. The stadium has a capacity of over 8,000 and has been the club's home ever since.

# Support

Bath City has a loyal and dedicated fan base, with supporters drawn from across the city and surrounding areas. The club's supporters are known for their passion and enthusiasm, with many traveling long distances to follow the team.

# Records

Bath City holds several records, including:

#Career

His experience as a priest deeply influenced his work in tiatrs, as he often wove moral lessons and spiritual themes into his performances.

## Tiatrs

Gracias' involvement in tiatrs began in the 1960s, and he quickly established himself as a talented actor, director, and writer. His tiatrs tackled a wide range of subjects, from social issues like poverty and inequality to cultural traditions and historical events. Gracias' contributions to the tiatr world earned him numerous accolades and a loyal following.

The film stars Tom Cruise, Ving Rhames, Simon Pegg, Rebecca Ferguson, Hayley Atwell, and Esai Morales.

article:
Constantine II of Greece

Constantine II (Greek: Κωνσταντῖνος Βʹ, Konstantínos II; 2 June 1940 – 10 January 2023) was the last King of Greece, reigning from 1964 until the abolition of the monarchy in 1973. He was the only son of King Paul of Greece and Queen Frederica, and succeeded his father to the throne in 1964.

# Early life

## World War II and the exile of the royal family

Constantine II was born in the Psychiko district of Athens, Greece, on 2 June 1940, during World War II. In 1941, when Constantine was just a year old, the Axis powers invaded Greece, forcing the royal family to flee the country. The family first went to Crete, where they were evacuated to Egypt by the British. They eventually settled in South Africa, where they lived in exile for the remainder of the war.

## After World War II and return to Greece

After the war, the royal family returned to Greece, where Constantine was educated at the Anavryta Classical Lyceum in Athens. In 1954, he went to the United Kingdom to attend the Victoria College at the University of Edinburgh, where he studied law.

# Crown Prince

## Education

As Crown Prince, Constantine pursued a military education, attending the Greek Military Academy and the Royal Navy Academy. He also studied at the NATO Defense College in Rome.

## Sailing and the Olympic Games

Constantine was an accomplished sailor and represented Greece at the 1960 Summer Olympics in Rome, competing in the Dragon class sailing event. He won a gold medal, becoming the first Greek monarch to win an Olympic gold medal.

# Reign

## Accession and marriage

Constantine ascended to the throne on 6 March 1964, following the death of his father, King Paul. On 18 September 1964, he married Princess Anne-Marie of Denmark, with whom he had five children.

## Apostasia of 1965

In 1965, Constantine attempted to dismiss the government of Prime Minister Georgios Papandreou, citing a lack of confidence in his leadership. However, this move was seen as unconstitutional, and it sparked a major political crisis in Greece. The crisis, known as the "Apostasia of 1965," ultimately led to the resignation of Constantine's government and the appointment of a new prime minister.

## Greek dictatorship of 1967–1974

On 21 April 1967, a group of army officers, led by Georgios Papadopoulos, seized power in a military coup. Constantine, who was in the palace with his family, attempted to rally the loyalist forces, but they were vastly outnumbered by the coup plotters. The royal family was forced to flee the palace, and the military junta took control of the government.

## Royal countercoup of 13 December 1967 and exile

On 13 December 1967, Constantine attempted a countercoup, hoping to restore democracy to Greece. However, the attempt failed, and the royal family was forced to flee the country. They settled in Rome, Italy, where they lived in exile for the next seven years.

# Restoration of democracy and the referendum

In 1974, following the collapse of the military junta, Greece returned to democracy. A referendum was held on 8 December 1974, in which the Greek people voted to abolish the monarchy. Constantine, who had returned to Greece for the referendum, accepted the result and went into exile once again.

# Life in exile after 1974

## Abortive conspiracies

In the years following the referendum, Constantine was involved in several abortive conspiracies to restore the monarchy. However, these attempts were unsuccessful, and he eventually abandoned his hopes of returning to the throne.

## 1993 visit to Greece

In 1993, Constantine visited Greece for the first time since his exile, sparking controversy and protests from republicans. However, the visit was seen as a step towards reconciliation between the former king and the Greek people.

## Legal quarrels over the royal properties

In the 1990s, Constantine became embroiled in a bitter dispute with the Greek government over the ownership of the royal properties. The dispute, which centered on the former royal palace in Athens, was eventually settled in 2003, with Constantine receiving a significant settlement.

# Later life

## Death

Constantine II died on 10 January 2023, at the age of 82, in a hospital in Athens. He was survived by his wife, Queen Anne-Marie, and their five children.

# Issue

Constantine II and Queen Anne-Marie had five children:

1. Crown Prince Pavlos (born 1967)
2. Prince Nikolaos (born 1969)
3. Princess Theodora (born 1983)
4. Prince Philippos (born 1986)
5. Princess Alexia (born 1965)

# Ancestry

Constantine II was a member of the House of Glücksburg, a branch of the House of Oldenburg. His ancestry includes:

* King Christian IX of Denmark
* King George I of Greece
* Emperor Frederick III of Germany
* King Frederick William III of Prussia

# Titles, styles and honours

## Titles and styles

* 1940–1964: His Royal Highness Prince Constantine of Greece and Denmark
* 1964–1973: His Majesty King Constantine II of the Hellenes
* 1973–2023: His Majesty King Constantine II of Greece (in pretence)

## National honours

article:
Beast (2022 Indian film)

Beast is a 2022 Indian Tamil-language action comedy film written and directed by Nelson Dilipkumar. The film stars Vijay and Pooja Hegde, with a supporting cast including Selvaraghavan, Yogi Babu, and Redin Kingsley. The movie follows the story of a former RAW agent who must rescue people held hostage in a shopping mall by terrorists.

# Plot

The film begins with Veeraraghavan (Vijay), a former RAW agent who is struggling to come to terms with the death of his wife, Preethi (Aparna Das). He is forced back into action when a group of terrorists, led by Umar Farooq (Lilliput), take a group of people hostage in a shopping mall in New Delhi. The terrorists demand the release of several high-profile prisoners, including Umar's brother, in exchange for the safety of the hostages. Veeraraghavan teams up with a police officer, Kathir (Selvaraghavan), to infiltrate the mall and rescue the hostages. As the story unfolds, Veeraraghavan discovers that the terrorists have a personal vendetta against him and that he is the key to their demands.

# Cast

* Vijay as Veeraraghavan
* Pooja Hegde as Preethi
* Selvaraghavan as Kathir
* Yogi Babu as Mathi
* Redin Kingsley as Irfan
* Aparna Das as Preethi (in flashbacks)
* Lilliput as Umar Farooq
* Shaji Chen as Abdul
* Sathish as Raj
* Ankur Ajit Vikal as Rajiv

# Production

## Development

The film was first announced in January 2020, with Nelson Dilipkumar set to direct and Vijay starring in the lead role. The movie was initially titled "Thalapathy 65" and was planned to be released in 2022. However, due to the COVID-19 pandemic, the production of the film was delayed.

## Pre-production

Pre-production work on the film began in December 2020, with the cast and crew undergoing quarantine before starting filming. The team also conducted a series of workshops to prepare for the action sequences and stunts in the film.

## Casting

Pooja Hegde was cast as the female lead opposite Vijay in February 2020. Selvaraghavan was cast as the main antagonist in the film, while Yogi Babu and Redin Kingsley were cast in supporting roles.

## Filming

Filming for the movie began on March 31, 2021, in Chennai. The team shot for over 100 days in various locations, including New Delhi, Chennai, and Hyderabad. The film's climax was shot in a massive set built in Chennai, with over 100 stuntmen and technicians involved in the shoot.

## Post-production

Post-production work on the film began in October 2021, with the editing team working on the final cut of the movie. The film's visual effects were handled by a team of technicians from the United States and India. The movie's sound design and mixing were done by a team of sound engineers from the UK.

# Music

The film's soundtrack was composed by Anirudh Ravichander, with lyrics written by Vivek and Ku. Karthik. The album features five songs, including the hit single "Jolly O Gymkhana". The song was released on February 19, 2022, and became a viral hit on social media.

# Marketing

The film's marketing campaign was handled by a team of experts from the UK and India. The team released a series of teasers and trailers on social media, which generated huge buzz and excitement among fans.

# Release

## Theatrical

Beast was released in theaters on April 13, 2022, in over 5,000 screens worldwide. The film received a massive response from fans, with many theaters reporting sold-out shows.

## Home media

The film was released on Amazon Prime Video on May 11, 2022, in over 240 countries and territories. The movie was also released on DVD and Blu-ray in June 2022.

# Reception

## Critical response

Beast received mixed reviews from critics, with many praising the film's action sequences and Vijay's performance. However, some critics felt that the movie's storyline was predictable and that the film's runtime was too long.

## Box office

Beast was a commercial success, grossing over ₹250 crore at the domestic box office. The film also performed well internationally, grossing over ₹150 crore in the US and UK.

# Accolades

Beast won several awards, including the Filmfare Award for Best Action Film and the SIIMA Award for Best Actor.

# Sequel

There have been reports of a potential sequel to Beast, with Nelson Dilipkumar set to direct and Vijay starring in the lead role. However, there has been no official confirmation from the team.

# Influence

Beast has been influenced by several Hollywood films, including the Die Hard series and the Taken series. The film's action sequences and stunts have been praised for their originality and execution.

# Remake

There have been reports of a potential remake of Beast in Hindi, with a leading Bollywood star set to play the lead role. However, there has been no official confirmation from the team.

# Notes

* Beast is Vijay's 65th film in his career.
* The film's budget was reported to be over ₹150 crore.

article:
House of the Dragon
=====================

House of the Dragon is a fantasy drama television series that premiered on HBO in 2022. The show is a prequel to the popular Game of Thrones series and is based on the book Fire & Blood by George R. R. Martin. The series is set 300 years before the events of Game of Thrones and follows the story of House Targaryen, a powerful and ancient family of dragonlords who ruled Westeros.

Cast and Characters
-------------------

The series features a talented ensemble cast, including:

* Paddy Considine as King Viserys I Targaryen, the ruler of the Seven Kingdoms
* Matt Smith as Prince Daemon Targaryen, the younger brother of King Viserys
* Olivia Cooke as Alicent Hightower, the daughter of the Hand of the King and a close friend of the royal family
* Emma D'Arcy as Princess Rhaenyra Targaryen, the daughter of King Viserys and heir to the Iron Throne
* Steve Toussaint as Lord Corlys Velaryon, a wealthy and influential lord who becomes a key player in the royal court
* Eve Best as Princess Rhaenys Velaryon, the wife of Lord Corlys and a member of the royal family
* Fabien Frankel as Ser Criston Cole, a skilled knight who becomes embroiled in the politics of the royal court

Episodes

Creed III
================

Creed III is a 2022 American sports drama film directed by Michael B. Jordan, who also stars in the title role. The film is the third installment in the Creed film series and the ninth film in the Rocky film franchise. The movie follows Adonis Creed, the son of Apollo Creed, as he faces a new challenge in the boxing ring and in his personal life.

Plot
-----

The film takes place several years after the events of Creed II. Adonis Creed (Michael B. Jordan) is now a successful boxer, having won the heavyweight championship of the world. He is married to Bianca (Tessa Thompson) and has a daughter, Amara. However, his life is turned upside down when a new challenger emerges in the form of Damian Anderson (Jonathan Majors), a boxer from his past who has a personal vendetta against Adonis.

As Adonis prepares to face Damian in the ring, he must also confront his own demons and the secrets of his past. Meanwhile, Bianca is struggling to balance her music career with her role as a mother, and Adonis's trainer, Duke (Wood Harris), is dealing with his own health issues.

* Florian Munteanu as Viktor Drago
* Selenis Leyva as Laura
* Thaddeus J. Mixson as young Adonis
* Spence Moore II as Kamari
* Mila Davis-Kent as Amara Creed

Production
------------

### Development

The development of Creed III began in 2018, shortly after the release of Creed II. Michael B. Jordan expressed interest in directing the film, and MGM and Warner Bros. Pictures agreed to let him take the helm. Jordan worked with writer Keenan Coogler to develop the script, which was influenced by the 1976 film Rocky.

### Pre-production

Pre-production on Creed III began in 2020, with Jordan and Coogler refining the script and assembling the cast and crew. The film's budget was estimated to be around $75 million.

### Filming

Principal photography on Creed III began in January 2021 and lasted for approximately 40 days. The film was shot on location in Atlanta, Georgia, and Las Vegas, Nevada. Jordan worked with cinematographer Kramer Morgenthau to create a unique visual style for the film, which incorporated a mix of close-ups and wide shots to capture the intensity of the boxing matches.

### Post-production

Post-production on Creed III began in March 2021 and lasted for several months. Jordan worked with editor Tyler Nelson to assemble the footage and create a cohesive narrative. The film's sound design and music were also completed during this time.

### Music

The score for Creed III was composed by Joseph Shirley, who incorporated a mix of electronic and orchestral elements to create a unique sound. The film's soundtrack also features several hip-hop and R&B tracks, including songs by Kendrick Lamar and J. Cole.

Release
--------

Creed III was released in the United States on March 3, 2022. The film was distributed by MGM and Warner Bros. Pictures and was released in a wide range of formats, including IMAX and Dolby Cinema.

### Home media

Creed III was released on DVD and Blu-ray on June 28, 2022. The film was also made available for streaming on various platforms, including Amazon Prime Video and HBO Max.

Reception

### Box office

article:
Hunting Success

Hunting success refers to the effectiveness of a predator, whether animal or human, in capturing and killing its prey. This concept is crucial in understanding the dynamics of predator-prey relationships, the evolution of hunting strategies, and the impact of hunting on ecosystems. Hunting success is a complex phenomenon influenced by various factors, including the characteristics of the predator and prey, the environment, and the hunting methods employed.

# Definition

Hunting success can be defined as the proportion of hunting attempts that result in a successful kill. It is a measure of a predator's ability to capture and kill its prey, and it is often expressed as a percentage or a ratio of successful hunts to total hunts. Hunting success is an important metric in ecology and wildlife management, as it helps to understand the dynamics of predator-prey relationships and the impact of hunting on ecosystems.

# Hunting success in animals

Hunting success varies widely among different animal species. Some predators, such as lions and wolves, have high hunting success rates, while others, such as solitary predators like tigers and bears, have lower success rates.

## List of animals by hunting success rate

Here is a list of some animals by their hunting success rates:

* Lions: 50-60%
* Wolves: 40-50%
* Tigers: 10-20%
* Bears: 5-15%
* Cheetahs: 40-50%
* Leopards: 30-40%
* Hyenas: 20-30%
* Wild dogs: 60-70%

## Reasons for high hunting success

Several factors contribute to high hunting success in animals. These include:

* Social hunting: Many successful predators, such as lions and wolves, hunt in groups. This allows them to coordinate their attacks, surround their prey, and increase their chances of success.
* Specialized hunting strategies: Some predators, such as cheetahs and leopards, have evolved specialized hunting strategies that allow them to catch their prey off guard. Cheetahs, for example, use their speed to chase down their prey, while leopards use their agility and stealth to stalk their prey.
* Strong senses: Many successful predators have strong senses, such as vision, hearing, and smell, that allow them to detect and track their prey.

# Kill rates

Kill rates are a measure of a predator's hunting success, expressed as the number of kills per unit of time or per unit of effort. Kill rates can vary widely among different predators and ecosystems. For example, a study of lions in the Serengeti found that they had a kill rate of 1.4 kills per day, while a study of wolves in Yellowstone found that they had a kill rate of 0.5 kills per day.

# Factors influencing success

Several factors can influence a predator's hunting success. These include:

## Selective feeding

Selective feeding refers to the tendency of predators to target certain prey species or individuals based on their characteristics, such as size, age, or vulnerability. This can increase a predator's hunting success by allowing them to focus on the most vulnerable or profitable prey.

## Social and solitary predators

Social predators, such as lions and wolves, often have higher hunting success rates than solitary predators, such as tigers and bears. This is because social predators can coordinate their attacks and surround their prey, increasing their chances of success.

## Hunting methods

Different hunting methods can affect a predator's hunting success. For example, predators that use ambush tactics, such as leopards and tigers, often have higher success rates than those that use chase tactics, such as cheetahs and hyenas.

## Environmental influences

Environmental factors, such as vegetation cover, terrain, and weather, can influence a predator's hunting success. For example, predators that hunt in areas with dense vegetation may have lower success rates than those that hunt in open areas.

## Vegetative cover

Vegetative cover can affect a predator's hunting success by providing cover for both the predator and the prey. Predators that hunt in areas with dense vegetation may have lower success rates than those that hunt in open areas.

# In human hunters

Hunting success in humans is influenced by many of the same factors that affect animal predators.

## Hunting success in humans

Human hunting success rates vary widely depending on the type of hunting, the experience and skill of the hunter, and the environment. For example, a study of bow hunters in the United States found that they had a success rate of 20-30%, while a study of rifle hunters in Africa found that they had a success rate of 50-60%.

## Factors influencing success of human hunters

Several factors can influence a human hunter's success. These include:

* Experience and skill: More experienced and skilled hunters tend to have higher success rates.
* Type of hunting: Different types of hunting, such as bow hunting and rifle hunting, can affect a hunter's success rate.
* Environment: Environmental factors, such as terrain and vegetation cover, can influence a hunter's success.

## Hunting types and methods

Different hunting types and methods can affect a hunter's success. For example, hunters who use tree stands or blinds may have higher success rates than those who hunt on foot.

## Impact

Human hunting can have significant impacts on ecosystems, including the depletion of prey populations and the disruption of predator-prey relationships. Therefore, it is essential to manage hunting practices sustainably to minimize these impacts.

# See also

* Predator-prey relationships
* Hunting strategies
* Wildlife management
* Conservation biology

Vikram (2022 film)

Vikram is a 2022 Indian Tamil-language action thriller film written and directed by Lokesh Kanagaraj. The film stars Kamal Haasan, Vijay Sethupathi, and Fahadh Faasil in the lead roles, with Shivani Narayanan, Kalidas Jayaram, Narain, and Arjun Das in supporting roles. The film marks the return of Kamal Haasan to the big screen after a gap of four years and is the 232nd film of his career.

# Plot

The film revolves around a retired police officer, Amar (Kamal Haasan), who sets out to avenge the death of his son, a police officer who was killed by a group of gangsters. Amar teams up with a young police officer, Prabhanjan (Kalidas Jayaram), to take down the gangsters. However, things take a turn when Amar's plans are thwarted by a mysterious figure, Sandhanam (Vijay Sethupathi), who seems to be one step ahead of him. As the story unfolds, Amar discovers that Sandhanam is a former gangster who has turned against his former associates and is now working to take them down. The two form an unlikely alliance to take down the gangsters, but their motives are not entirely clear.

# Cast

* Kamal Haasan as Amar
* Vijay Sethupathi as Sandhanam
* Fahadh Faasil as Agent Lawrence
* Shivani Narayanan as Gayathri
* Kalidas Jayaram as Prabhanjan
* Narain as Bejoy
* Arjun Das as Anbu
* Swathishta Krishnan as Nithya

# Production

## Development

The film was announced in November 2019, with Lokesh Kanagaraj directing and Kamal Haasan starring in the lead role. The film was initially titled "Evanendru Ninaithaai" but was later changed to "Vikram". The film's script was written by Lokesh Kanagaraj and his team, which included Rathna Kumar and Deeraj Vaidy.

## Casting

The film's cast was announced in January 2020, with Vijay Sethupathi and Fahadh Faasil joining the cast. Shivani Narayanan, Kalidas Jayaram, Narain, and Arjun Das were also cast in supporting roles. The film marked the Tamil debut of Fahadh Faasil, who had previously acted in Malayalam films.

## Filming

The film's principal photography began in July 2021 and was wrapped up in January 2022. The film was shot in various locations in India, including Chennai, Hyderabad, and Mumbai. The film's action sequences were choreographed by Anbariv, who had previously worked on films like "Kaithi" and "Master".

# Music

The film's soundtrack was composed by Anirudh Ravichander, who had previously worked on films like "Kaththi" and "Thaanaa Serndha Koottam". The film's score was composed by Phil Barrie, who had previously worked on films like "Kaithi" and "Master". The film's soundtrack consisted of five songs, including "Pathala Pathala", "Vikram Title Track", "Porkanda Singam", "Wasted", and "Oh Sita Hey Rama".

# Marketing

The film's marketing campaign was handled by Raaj Kamal Films International, which had previously handled the marketing of Kamal Haasan's films. The film's trailer was released on May 18, 2022, and received over 10 million views on YouTube within 24 hours.

# Release

## Theatrical

The film was released on June 3, 2022, in theaters worldwide. The film was released in Tamil, Telugu, Malayalam, and Kannada languages.

### Screenings and statistics

The film was screened in over 1,000 theaters worldwide, including 450 theaters in Tamil Nadu. The film had a runtime of 176 minutes and was rated U/A by the Central Board of Film Certification.

## Distribution

The film's distribution rights were acquired by Red Giant Movies, which had previously distributed films like "Viswasam" and "Petta".

## Home media and screenplay

The film's home media rights were acquired by Amazon Prime Video, which released the film on its platform on July 8, 2022. The film's screenplay was released on July 15, 2022, and was available for purchase on Amazon.

## Film festival

The film was screened at the 2022 Busan International Film Festival, which was held in October 2022.

# Reception

## Box office

The film grossed over ₹500 crore at the box office worldwide, making it one of the highest-grossing Tamil films of all time. The film grossed over ₹200 crore in Tamil Nadu and over ₹100 crore in Andhra Pradesh and Telangana.

## Critical reception

The film received positive reviews from critics, with many praising the film's action sequences, direction, and performances. The film holds a rating of 8.1/10 on IMDB and 4.5/5 on Amazon Prime Video.

## Accolades

The film was nominated for several awards, including the Filmfare Awards South and the SIIMA Awards. The film won several awards, including the Edison Award for Best Direction and the Ananda Vikatan Cinema Award for Best Film.

# Future

A sequel to the film was announced in July 2022, with Lokesh Kanagaraj directing and Kamal Haasan starring in the lead role. The film is expected to go into production in 2023 and release in 2024.

# Notes

Amber Heard
================

Amber Laura Heard is an American actress and model. Born on April 22, 1986, in Austin, Texas, Heard rose to prominence in the late 2000s for her roles in various films and television series. She has since become a prominent figure in Hollywood, known for her versatility and range as an actress.

Early Life
------------

Protests against the Russian invasion of Ukraine

The 2022 Russian invasion of Ukraine sparked widespread protests and condemnation around the world. In Russia, various groups and individuals spoke out against the invasion, despite the risks of persecution and censorship. Outside Russia, protests were held in many countries, and people showed their support for Ukraine in various ways.

# In Russia

## Academics

Russian academics were among the first to speak out against the invasion. On February 24, 2022, a group of Russian scholars and scientists published an open letter condemning the invasion and calling for its immediate withdrawal. The letter was signed by over 100 academics from various institutions, including the Russian Academy of Sciences. Some academics also released individual statements, such as the physicist and Nobel laureate, Andre Geim, who called the invasion a "crazy and destructive decision."

Russian activists, including those from opposition groups and human rights organizations, were quick to organize protests and rallies against the invasion. Other military personnel, such as the former commander of the Russian Navy, Admiral Viktor Kravchenko, publicly criticized the invasion.

## Organizations

## Politicians and government officials

Other politicians, such as the leader of the Russian opposition party, Yabloko, Nikolay Rybakov, also expressed their opposition.

## Protests

Spider-Man: Across the Spider-Verse

Spider-Man: Across the Spider-Verse is a 2022 American animated superhero film produced by Columbia Pictures and Sony Pictures Animation in association with Marvel Entertainment. The film is a sequel to Spider-Man: Into the Spider-Verse (2018) and follows Miles Morales as he teams up with Spider-Man 2099 to stop a threat to the multiverse.

#Plot

The film takes place after the events of the first movie, where Miles Morales is struggling to balance his life as Spider-Man with his personal life. He is soon visited by Spider-Man 2099, who warns him of a threat to the multiverse. The two Spider-Men team up to stop the villainous Spot, who has gained the ability to travel through dimensions. Along the way, they meet new Spider-Men from different dimensions, including Spider-Woman and Spider-Man Noir.

As they journey through the multiverse, the Spider-Men encounter various obstacles and challenges, including different versions of familiar villains. They also discover that the Spot is working for a mysterious figure known as the Kingpin, who is seeking to gain control over the multiverse.

The Spider-Men eventually discover that the Kingpin's plan involves using a device that can manipulate the fabric of reality. They must work together to stop the Kingpin and the Spot, and save the multiverse from destruction.

article:
2023 Writers Guild of America strike

The 2023 Writers Guild of America strike is an ongoing labor dispute between the Writers Guild of America (WGA) and the Alliance of Motion Picture and Television Producers (AMPTP), which represents film and television producers. The strike began on May 2, 2023, after negotiations between the two parties failed to reach a new collective bargaining agreement.

Issues in the strike

The WGA is seeking improvements in several areas, including compensation, benefits, and working conditions. Key issues in the strike include:

* Increased residuals for writers working on streaming platforms
* Improved script parity, which would require producers to pay writers equally for scripts written for traditional television and streaming services
* Enhanced benefits for writers, including improved health insurance and pension plans
* Stronger regulations on the use of artificial intelligence in writing rooms
* Greater transparency in the hiring process for writers

The WGA is also seeking to address the issue of "mini-rooms," where a small group of writers are hired to work on a project for a short period of time, often without benefits or residuals.

Timeline of negotiations and strike activity

## April 2023

Negotiations between the WGA and AMPTP began in April 2023, with the WGA presenting its initial proposal for a new collective bargaining agreement. The proposal included many of the key issues listed above, and the WGA stated that it was seeking significant improvements in compensation and benefits for writers.

## May 2023

After several weeks of negotiations, the WGA and AMPTP failed to reach an agreement, and the WGA announced that it would go on strike. The strike began on May 2, 2023, and immediately impacted many film and television productions.

## June 2023

In June, the WGA and AMPTP resumed negotiations, but the talks were tense and ultimately unproductive. The WGA accused the AMPTP of not taking the negotiations seriously, and the AMPTP claimed that the WGA was making unrealistic demands.

## July 2023

In July, the strike continued, with many writers participating in picket lines and rallies. The WGA also launched a social media campaign, using the hashtag #WGAStrong to raise awareness and build support for the strike.

## August 2023

In August, the WGA and AMPTP reached a tentative agreement on a new collective bargaining agreement, but the deal was rejected by the WGA membership. The WGA stated that the agreement did not address many of the key issues in the strike, and that it would continue to negotiate for a better deal.

## September 2023

In September, the strike continued, with the WGA and AMPTP engaging in intermittent negotiations. The WGA also announced that it would be holding a series of town hall meetings, where writers could discuss the strike and the issues at hand.

## October 2023

In October, the strike entered its sixth month, with no end in sight. The WGA and AMPTP were still engaged in negotiations, but the talks were slow and unproductive. The WGA stated that it was committed to continuing the strike until it reached a fair and equitable agreement.

WGA negotiating committee

The WGA negotiating committee is led by Chris Keyser, a veteran television writer and producer. The committee also includes several other experienced writers and producers, including David Goodman, Meredith Stiehm, and Billy Ray.

Productions impacted

The 2023 WGA strike has impacted many film and television productions, including:

* The Tonight Show Starring Jimmy Fallon
* Saturday Night Live
* The Late Show with Stephen Colbert
* The Daily Show
* Late Night with Seth Meyers
* The Simpsons
* South Park
* American Horror Story
* The Walking Dead

Response

## Actors during the WGA strike

Many actors have expressed support for the WGA strike, including several high-profile stars. Some actors have also participated in picket lines and rallies, and many have spoken out on social media using the hashtag #WGAStrong.

## Elected officials

Several elected officials have also expressed support for the WGA strike, including California Governor Gavin Newsom and Los Angeles Mayor Eric Garcetti.

## Other unions

Many other unions have expressed support for the WGA strike, including the Screen Actors Guild (SAG-AFTRA), the Directors Guild of America (DGA), and the International Alliance of Theatrical Stage Employees (IATSE).

### Foreign unions

Several foreign unions have also expressed support for the WGA strike, including the Writers' Guild of Canada and the Australian Writers' Guild.

## Film and television executives

Some film and television executives have expressed support for the WGA strike, including several high-profile producers and writers. However, many others have opposed the strike, and some have accused the WGA of being unrealistic and inflexible.

## Strikebreaking efforts

There have been several reports of strikebreaking efforts, including the use of non-union writers and the hiring of replacement writers. The WGA has condemned these efforts, and has vowed to take action against any producers or studios that engage in strikebreaking.

article:
David Crosby
================

David Crosby was an American singer, songwriter, and musician. He was a founding member of the Byrds and Crosby, Stills, Nash & Young, and also had a successful solo career. Crosby is known for his distinctive voice, songwriting skills, and activism.

Early years
------------

David Van Cortlandt Crosby was born on August 14, 1941, in Los Angeles, California. His father, Floyd Crosby, was a cinematographer who won an Academy Award for his work on the film "Tabu: A Story of the South Seas." Crosby's mother, Aliph Van Cortlandt Whitehead, was a pianist and a singer. Crosby grew up in a musical family and was exposed to jazz and classical music from an early age.

Crosby attended Cate School in Carpinteria, California, and later studied drama at Santa Barbara City College. However, he dropped out of college to pursue a career in music. Crosby began his music career in the early 1960s, playing in various bands and singing in folk clubs in Los Angeles.

Musical career
----------------

### The Byrds

In 1964, Crosby co-founded the Byrds with Jim McGuinn, Gene Clark, and Chris Hillman. The band's music was a fusion of folk rock, psychedelic rock, and country rock. Crosby sang lead vocals on many of the band's songs, including "Turn! Turn! Turn!" and "Eight Miles High." The Byrds were one of the most influential bands of the 1960s, and their music had a significant impact on the development of rock music.

Crosby left the Byrds in 1967 due to creative differences and personal tensions within the band. He went on to pursue a solo career and to collaborate with other musicians.

### Crosby, Stills, Nash & Young

In 1968, Crosby joined forces with Stephen Stills and Graham Nash to form Crosby, Stills & Nash. The trio's music was a blend of folk rock, psychedelic rock, and country rock. Their debut album, "Crosby, Stills & Nash," was released in 1969 and was a critical and commercial success.

In 1969, Neil Young joined the band, and they became known as Crosby, Stills, Nash & Young. The band's music was characterized by their harmonious vocals and their eclectic blend of rock, folk, and country music. They released several successful albums, including "Déjà Vu" and "4 Way Street."

Crosby, Stills, Nash & Young were one of the most influential and successful bands of the 1970s. They performed at the Woodstock festival in 1969 and were known for their activism and their music.

### 1971–2022: Solo career and Crosby & Nash

In 1971, Crosby released his debut solo album, "If I Could Only Remember My Name." The album was a critical and commercial success, and it established Crosby as a solo artist.

In the 1970s and 1980s, Crosby released several successful solo albums, including "Oh Yes I Can" and "Thousand Roads." He also collaborated with Graham Nash on several albums, including "Graham Nash/David Crosby" and "Whistling Down the Wire."

In the 1990s and 2000s, Crosby continued to release solo albums and to collaborate with other musicians. He also performed with Crosby, Stills, Nash & Young on several occasions.

### 1996–2004: CPR

In 1996, Crosby formed the band CPR with guitarist James Raymond and keyboardist Jeff Pevar. The band released several albums, including "CPR" and "Just Like Gravity." CPR's music was a blend of rock, folk, and country music.

article:
Scott Hall
================

Scott Hall was an American professional wrestler, best known for his tenures in the World Wrestling Federation (WWF, now WWE) and World Championship Wrestling (WCW). With a career spanning over three decades, Hall became a household name, known for his charismatic personality, exceptional in-ring skills, and iconic feuds.

Early Life
-----------

Born on October 20, 1958, in St. Mary's County, Maryland, Scott Hall grew up in a military family, moving frequently throughout his childhood. Hall developed an interest in sports, particularly wrestling, and began training at a young age. After high school, Hall attended St. Mary's College of Maryland, where he played basketball and football.

Professional Wrestling Career
=============================

Early Career (1984–1985)
-------------------------

Hall began his professional wrestling career in 1984, working for various independent promotions in the Mid-Atlantic region. He adopted the ring name "Scott Hall" and quickly gained recognition for his technical grappling skills and charismatic persona.

American Wrestling Association (1985–1989)
-----------------------------------------

In 1985, Hall joined the American Wrestling Association (AWA), where he worked alongside notable wrestlers such as Verne Gagne and Larry Zbyszko. During his time in the AWA, Hall developed a reputation as a solid in-ring performer and began to build a loyal fan base.

World Wrestling Federation Tryouts (1987, 1990)
---------------------------------------------

Hall twice attended tryouts for the World Wrestling Federation (WWF), first in 1987 and again in 1990. Although he was not initially signed, Hall's second tryout caught the attention of WWF owner Vince McMahon, who saw potential in the young wrestler.

World Championship Wrestling (1989)
-----------------------------------

In 1989, Hall joined World Championship Wrestling (WCW), where he adopted the ring name "The Diamond Studd." Hall's time in WCW was marked by a series of lackluster feuds and a struggling character. Despite his efforts, Hall failed to gain significant traction in the promotion.

International Promotions (1990–1991)
--------------------------------------

Following his departure from WCW, Hall worked for various international promotions, including New Japan Pro-Wrestling (NJPW) and the Catch Wrestling Association (CWA). During this period, Hall refined his craft, honing his skills and developing a distinctive style.

Return to WCW (1991–1992)
-------------------------

In 1991, Hall returned to WCW, this time as a member of the stable "The Diamond Exchange." Hall's second stint in WCW was marked by improved performances and a more defined character. However, he still struggled to find his place in the promotion.

World Wrestling Federation (1992–1996)
--------------------------------------

Debut and Various Feuds (1992–1993)
--------------------------------------

In 1992, Hall joined the World Wrestling Federation (WWF), debuting as "Razor Ramon," a charismatic and confident wrestler. Hall's WWF debut was met with immediate success, as he engaged in a series of high-profile feuds with wrestlers such as Bret Hart, Diesel, and Shawn Michaels.

Record-Setting Intercontinental Champion (1993–1996)
---------------------------------------------------

In 1993, Hall won his first WWF Intercontinental Championship, beginning a record-setting reign that lasted over a year. During his time as champion, Hall defended the title against a range of opponents, solidifying his position as one of the WWF's top stars.

Second Return to WCW (1996–2000)
-------------------------------

New World Order (1996–1998)
---------------------------

In 1996, Hall returned to WCW, joining the revolutionary stable "New World Order" (nWo) alongside Kevin Nash and Hollywood Hulk Hogan. The nWo's arrival marked a significant shift in the professional wrestling landscape, as the group's anti-authority, outsider persona resonated with fans.

nWo Reunion and Championship Reigns (1999–2000)
---------------------------------------------

Following a brief hiatus, Hall reunited with the nWo in 1999, engaging in a series of high-profile feuds and winning multiple championships, including the WCW United States Heavyweight Championship and the WCW World Tag Team Championship.

Extreme Championship Wrestling and Japan (2000–2001)
-------------------------------------------------

In 2000, Hall joined Extreme Championship Wrestling (ECW), where he worked alongside wrestlers such as Tommy Dreamer and Rob Van Dam. Hall's time in ECW was marked by a series of intense matches and a renewed focus on his in-ring skills.

Return to WWF/E (2002)
----------------------

In 2002, Hall returned to the WWF, now rebranded as World Wrestling Entertainment (WWE). Hall's second stint in WWE was marked by a series of nostalgic matches and a brief alliance with his old nWo stablemates.

Total Nonstop Action Wrestling (2002–2005, 2007–2008)
---------------------------------------------------

In 2002, Hall joined Total Nonstop Action Wrestling (TNA), where he worked alongside wrestlers such as Jeff Jarrett and AJ Styles. Hall's time in TNA was marked by a series of high-profile feuds and a renewed focus on his in-ring skills.

Return to the WWC (2007)
-------------------------

In 2007, Hall returned to the World Wrestling Council (WWC), a promotion based in Puerto Rico. Hall's time in WWC was marked by a series of nostalgia-tinged matches and a brief reign as WWC Universal Heavyweight Champion.

Juggalo Championship Wrestling (2007–2009)
------------------------------------------

In 2007, Hall joined Juggalo Championship Wrestling (JCW), a promotion founded by Insane Clown Posse. Hall's time in JCW was marked by a series of intense matches and a renewed focus on his in-ring skills.

Return to TNA (2010)
----------------------

In 2010, Hall returned to TNA, engaging in a series of high-profile feuds and brief alliances with wrestlers such as Kevin Nash and Eric Young.

Late Career (2010–2021)
-------------------------

Hall's later career was marked by a series of sporadic appearances and a continued focus on his in-ring skills. Despite health issues and personal struggles, Hall remained a beloved figure in the professional wrestling community.

Legal Issues
------------

Hall has faced numerous legal issues throughout his career, including multiple arrests for driving under the influence and a 2012 arrest for disorderly conduct.

Personal Life
-------------

Hall has been married twice and has two children. He has struggled with addiction and personal demons throughout his life, but has remained a devoted father and husband.

Death
------

Scott Hall passed away on March 14, 2022, at the age of 63. His death was met with an outpouring of tributes and condolences from the professional wrestling community.

----------

Hall has made numerous television appearances throughout his career, including a 1996 guest spot on "The Larry Sanders Show" and a 2011 appearance on "The Tonight Show with Jay Leno."

-------------

Hall has been featured in numerous video games, including the "WWE 2K" series and "TNA Impact!"

article:
Lightyear (film)

Lightyear is a 2022 American computer-animated science fiction action-adventure film produced by Walt Disney Pictures and Pixar Animation Studios. The film is a spin-off of the Toy Story franchise and explores the origins of the character Buzz Lightyear. Directed by Angus MacLane and written by MacLane and Jason Headley, the film features a voice cast that includes Chris Evans, Keke Palmer, Peter Sohn, and James Brolin.

Plot

The film takes place in a distant future where Buzz Lightyear, a space ranger, is tasked with exploring the galaxy and discovering new worlds. After being stranded on a hostile planet, Lightyear must navigate through treacherous terrain and fight off alien creatures to survive. Along the way, he meets a group of recruits who join him on his mission, including Alisha Hawthorne, a skilled space ranger, and Sox, a robot companion.

As Lightyear and his team journey through the galaxy, they discover a sinister plot by an evil alien overlord, Emperor Zurg, who seeks to destroy entire star systems. Lightyear and his team must use their skills and ingenuity to defeat Zurg and save the galaxy.

Voice cast

* Chris Evans as Buzz Lightyear
* Keke Palmer as Alisha Hawthorne
* Peter Sohn as Sox
* James Brolin as Emperor Zurg
* Taika Waititi as Mo Morrison
* Dale Soules as Darby Steel
* Uzo Aduba as Commander Hawthorne

Production

Development

The idea for Lightyear was conceived by Angus MacLane, a veteran Pixar animator and director. MacLane had always been fascinated by the character of Buzz Lightyear and saw an opportunity to explore the character's origins in a feature film. The film was officially announced in December 2019, with MacLane attached to direct and Jason Headley set to write the screenplay.

Casting

Chris Evans was cast as the voice of Buzz Lightyear in December 2019. Evans had previously expressed his admiration for the character and was thrilled to take on the role. Keke Palmer was cast as Alisha Hawthorne, a skilled space ranger, in July 2020. The rest of the voice cast was announced in October 2020.

Animation and design

The film's animation was produced by Pixar Animation Studios, with a team of over 500 artists and technicians working on the film. The film's visual style was inspired by classic science fiction films, including Star Wars and Blade Runner. The film's characters and environments were designed to be highly detailed and realistic, with a focus on creating a sense of immersion and authenticity.

Music

The film's score was composed by Michael Giacchino, who had previously worked on several Pixar films, including Up and Inside Out. The score was performed by the Hollywood Symphony Orchestra and features a mix of orchestral and electronic elements.

Marketing

The film's marketing campaign was launched in October 2020, with the release of a teaser trailer. The trailer featured a dramatic shot of Buzz Lightyear standing on a cliff, looking out at the galaxy. The trailer was widely praised for its epic scope and sense of adventure.

Release

Theatrical

Lightyear was released in theaters on June 17, 2022. The film was released in IMAX and 3D formats, as well as standard 2D. The film received a wide release, playing on over 4,000 screens in the United States.

Ban and censorship

The film was banned in several countries, including the United Arab Emirates and Saudi Arabia, due to its depiction of same-sex relationships. The film's censoring was widely criticized by LGBTQ+ rights organizations and film critics.

Home media

Lightyear was released on digital platforms on August 3, 2022, and on Blu-ray and DVD on September 13, 2022. The film's home media release featured several bonus features, including deleted scenes and a making-of documentary.

Reception

Streaming viewership

Lightyear was released on Disney+ on August 3, 2022, and became one of the most-watched films on the platform. According to Disney, the film was streamed by over 1.7 million households in its first week of release.

Box office

Lightyear performed moderately well at the box office, grossing over $225 million worldwide. The film's box office performance was affected by the COVID-19 pandemic, as well as increased competition from other summer blockbusters.

Critical response

Lightyear received mixed reviews from film critics, with some praising the film's visuals and action sequences, while others criticized the film's storytelling and characters. The film holds a 74% approval rating on Rotten Tomatoes, based on 222 reviews.

Accolades

Lightyear received several award nominations, including a Critics' Choice Movie Award nomination for Best Visual Effects. The film also received a Saturn Award nomination for Best Animated Film.

Notes

* Lightyear is the first Pixar film to be released in IMAX format.
* The film's score was performed by the Hollywood Symphony Orchestra.
* The film's visual effects were created by over 500 artists and technicians.

References

* None

article:
Women's Premier League (Cricket)

The Women's Premier League (WPL) is a professional women's T20 cricket league in India, established by the Board of Control for Cricket in India (BCCI) in 2022. The league is designed to promote women's cricket in India and provide a platform for Indian and international players to showcase their skills.

# History

The idea of a women's T20 league in India was first proposed by the BCCI in 2018, with the aim of increasing participation and interest in women's cricket. However, the plan was put on hold due to various reasons, including the COVID-19 pandemic. In 2022, the BCCI announced the launch of the Women's Premier League, with five teams participating in the inaugural season. The league is expected to play a significant role in promoting women's cricket in India and providing opportunities for young players to develop their skills.

# Organisation

The Women's Premier League is governed by the Board of Control for Cricket in India (BCCI), which is responsible for the overall administration and management of the league. The BCCI has established a separate committee to oversee the operations of the WPL, which includes representatives from various stakeholders, including team owners, players, and sponsors.

# Teams

The inaugural season of the Women's Premier League features five teams, each representing a different city in India. The teams are:

* Delhi Capitals Women
* Gujarat Giants Women
* Mumbai Indians Women
* Royal Challengers Bangalore Women
* UP Warriorz Women

Each team has a squad of 15 players, including a mix of Indian and international players. The teams are owned by private franchises, which are responsible for managing the team's operations, including player recruitment, coaching, and marketing.

# Tournament seasons and results

The Women's Premier League is played in a round-robin format, with each team playing the other teams twice. The top three teams in the league table qualify for the playoffs, with the top team earning a direct spot in the final. The second and third teams play each other in the eliminator, with the winner advancing to the final.

## Finals

The final of the Women's Premier League is played between the top team in the league table and the winner of the eliminator. The final is a one-off match, with the winner being crowned the champion of the WPL.

## Teams' performances

The teams' performances in the Women's Premier League are evaluated based on their win-loss record, with the team earning two points for a win and zero points for a loss. The team with the highest number of points at the end of the league stage is declared the winner.

# Records and statistics

The Women's Premier League has seen several records and milestones being achieved by players and teams. Some of the notable records include:

* Highest score: 150* by [player name] (team name) against (opponent team) in (season)
* Highest partnership: 100* by [player name] and [player name] (team name) against (opponent team) in (season)
* Best bowling figures: 5/10 by [player name] (team name) against (opponent team) in (season)

# Financial background

The Women's Premier League is a professionally managed league, with a significant investment in player contracts, coaching, and marketing. The league is funded by a combination of team owners, sponsors, and broadcast rights. The BCCI has also invested a significant amount in the league, with the aim of promoting women's cricket in India.

# Player auction

The Women's Premier League features a player auction, where teams bid for players to join their squad. The auction is held before the start of each season, with teams having a fixed budget to spend on player contracts. The auction is a key part of the WPL, with teams competing fiercely to sign top players.

# Broadcasting

The Women's Premier League is broadcast live on television and streaming platforms, with the BCCI having partnered with various broadcasters to showcase the league. The league is also streamed live on the BCCI's website and mobile app, with fans able to watch matches live and catch up on highlights.

2022–23 I-League

The 2022–23 I-League is the 16th season of the I-League, the second tier of Indian football league system. The season started on 12 November 2022 and is scheduled to conclude on 12 March 2023.

Changes from last season

### Disbanded clubs

Revised Estates, the reserve team of Indian Super League club Chennaiyin, withdrew from the league due to the All India Football Federation's (AIFF) new regulations. The team was replaced by Inter Kashi, the winners of the 2022 I-League Qualifiers.

### Reinstated clubs

Aizawl and Rajasthan United, who were relegated to the I-League 2nd Division last season, were reinstated to the league after the AIFF's decision to increase the number of teams in the league from 13 to 14.

The league format remains the same as last season, with all teams playing each other in a double round-robin format, followed by the top two teams playing each other in a title decider match.
